Award.AwardTitle: GOALI: WERF: Bioaugmentation of activated sludge with high activity nitrifying granules/flocs: population selection, survival, biokinetics

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1603707
Stensel

Municipal wastewater treatment plants are faced with new goals for nitrogen removal that are difficult to meet with limited space in urban areas. In cooperation with the DC Water (Washington DC), as well as King County (KC, Seattle) and Los Angeles County (LAC) water treatment facilities, the PIs intend to demonstrate and develop fundamental design information for an innovative bioaugmentation technology that meets high nitrogen removal standards and greatly reduces space, capital cost, energy, and chemical requirements. The proposed project examines ways to reduce operating costs for nitrogen removal using both pilot plant (at the participating plants) and lab-scale testing.

Two systems are proposed. System I (operated at KC and LAC) develops nitritation granular sludge from sidestream centrate treatment that is added to the mainstream process. Granular sludge is a new type of round shaped dense rapid settling biomass of 1.0 to 3.0 mm diameter, resulting in bioreactors with greatly reduced area in contrast to conventional processes with lighter, less dense flocculent sludge, process intensification. The ability to uncouple the sludge retention time of the granules and flocculent sludge (selective retention) provides a long sludge retention time to increase the volumetric nitrification capacity of the mainstream significantly due to the high solids concentration of dense granules. Granular sludge bioreactors have contributed to a wastewater treatment revolution in Europe but are not yet implemented in the US, partly because aerobic granular sludge technology cannot be readily adapted to most existing activated sludge process reactor geometries. System II (operated at DC water) provides an enriched high activity nitritation floc from the cyclone separation overflow from a sidestream anammox process, which is fed to the mainstream to also intensify the volumetric nitrification capacity and promote a nitrite shunt in the main plant. Bioaugmentation of nitritation flocs and granules will enable the PIs to intensify existing infrastructure and achieve higher efficiency in given space, while reducing oxygen and carbon demands. The granular and flocculent biomass microbial populations and their survival and fate will be followed by molecular tools, fundamental biokinetic tests and process simulation models. The proposed work advances transformational innovative biological treatment methods and a deeper understanding of the microbial selection principles of ammonium and nitrite oxidizing bacteria in bioaugmented systems. It will be unique in combining population dynamics, identity, and kinetic parameters of granules and flocs with the ultimate goal to engineer an effective compact short cut nitrogen removal process. An innovative feature is increasing the volumetric nitrification capacity without increasing tank volume by growing high activity nitrifiers (granules/flocs) in a side reactor and to then seed the mainstream treatment to increase the nitrifying biomass density and volumetric capacity. This project enhances infrastructure for research and education in environmental engineering by exposing students to granular sludge technology. The results will be broadly disseminated by presentations at conferences. The PIs will reach underrepresented groups at the K-12 and undergraduate level through the minority science and engineering program, and the mathematics, science, engineering achievement program. This program has a strong history of bringing minority students on campus for extended program for faculty lectures and laboratory visits in which the PIs have participated.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Though great progress in municipal and industrial wastewater treatment for effective removal of organic pollutants in compliance with the Clean Water Act there has been a continuing decline in surface water quality across the U.S. due to excess nutrients; nitrogen and phosphorus and accelerated eutrophication. However, nutrient removal requires another level of processing methods and costs. Over the past 30 years, processes that employ bacteria to convert nitrogen to nitrogen gas and consume phosphorus have been developed with biomass grown in flocculent suspensions called a flocculent activated sludge. Converting such system to include nutrient removal can more than double the tank volume needed.

Flocculent activated sludge has been used for over 100 years, but recently a new form of activated sludge,, called granular activated sludge, has been found possible by using special reactor operating methods. The granular sludge has a larger and denser structure with a spherical type morphology (Figure 1) and can be thicken to much higher concentrations so that the activated sludge processes can be operated with 2-3 times biomass concentration. In addition, all of the processes related to nitrogen and phosphorus removal can be carried out within a single granule. which reduces the complexity of the nutrient removal process and saves capital, energy, and chemical costs. Application of granular sludge has been limited to using sequencing batch reactors (SBRs), but most of existing facilities are continuous flow treatment systems. Our general research aim was to develop and demonstrate a system that could be used to upgrade existing continuous flow systems with granular sludge for biological nutrient removal.

Our research tested an innovative process for growing the granules in a sidestream system and adding them to the mainstream treatment system (Figure 2). The mainstream treatment process has  a hydraulic separator to allow the selective retention of granular sludge over flocculent sludge. The sidestream process treats a high nitrogen and phosphorus concentration reject liquid stream from processing the plant?s waste sludge. This method of adding microbial mass grown outside the mainstream system is called sidestream bioaugmentation.

Bench-scale laboratory studies identified the preferred type of granule to grow in sidestream. A pilot plant with the sidestream and mainstream systems was installed at the Seattle municipal wastewater treatment plant by the King County Wastewater Treatment Division. The mainstream process design volumes simulated that needed for only organic removal.

The sidestream treatment process, operated for 2 years, produced a granular activated sludge with over 94% granules and accomplished over 90% nitrogen removal. Acetate added to the process grew granules with phosphorus accumulation organisms (PAOs), which also carried out denitrification for nitrogen removal. Operating conditions that led to shortcut nitrogen removal for minimal acetate addition were identified and demonstrated. Kinetic and mass balance results provided information for future engineering design.

Granule sizes grown in the sidestream reactor ranged from 0.212 to 2.0 mm with an average from 1.3-1.5 mm. A parallel bench-scale study determined that a granule size in the range of 0.6 ? 1.0 mm provided the best kinetic activity and highest performance efficiency for nitrogen and phosphorus removal.

Laboratory work on the microbial composition through DNA extraction identity key microbial populations and the effect of the pilot plant operating conditions on their selection. We also found that the PAO growth was key to forming the granule sludge and that granules with PAO growth actually exist in current full-scale flocculent sludge treatment facilities. Our work provided a means of following full scale granular sludge and also how to enhance their productivity and proportion in activated sludge treatment.

The bioaugmented granules were sustained in the mainstream system and nitrogen and phosphorus removal was demonstrated. The hydraulic separator did not have as high a separation efficiency for granules and flocs as expected (40% versus 80%) but observations were made on the operation and hydraulic design for improved future performance. These results provided good direction for future research and plant upgrades from flocculent to granular sludge.

Support under this award has attracted underrepresented minority student for the Master program and woman to engineering in addition to two other students. Master?s degrees in environmental engineering were earned by two students and a PhD student has produced 2 paper submittals on microbial evaluation work as part of his PhD thesis. An undergraduate woman with us on this study found an increased interest in environmental engineering and will extend her education in this area in a master?s degree program next year. We have advanced environmental engineering and science education at the university level and has heightened the interest in applying this technology in our profession. Published papers, professional conference talks, and presentations to utilities and universities by us has helped our profession to understand how to apply granular sludge into continuous flow systems and important design and operating characteristics.
